editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Clois Hoffman sometimes called Sarlois Lorrique Otho sometimes called Charles Ferdinand; Duke of Prussia Rodorick or Rodorigo Lodowick Matthias Lucibella Jerom Stilt Duke of Austria John; Duke of Saxony Old Stilt Fibs Martha; Duchess of Luningberg Herald Lord Multiple speakers

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

front.head:
THE TRAGEDY OF HOFFMAN
OR A Revenge for a Father.
TO HIS MVCH Honoured Friend, Master Richard Kiluert.

div1.head: Act 1

sp.speaker: Hoffman.
sp.l: Hence Clouds of melancholy
I will be no longer subject to your schisms,
But thou dear soul, whose nerves and arteries
In dead resoundings summon up revenge,
And thou shalt hate, be but appeased sweet hearse
The dead remembrance of my living father
sp.stage: strikes ope a curtaine where appeares a body.
sp.l: And with a heart as air, swift as thought
I will excuse justly in such a cause
Where truth leadeth, what coward would not fight
Ill acts move some, but mine is a cause is right
See the powers of heaven in apparitions
And sight full aspects as incensed
That I thus tardy am to do an act
which justice and a fathers death exits,
Like threatening meteors antedates destruction.
Again I come I come, I come,
Be silent thou effigies of fair virtue
That like a goodly scion wert plucked up
By murderous, winds, infectious blasts and gusts
I will not leave thee, until like thyself,
I have made thy enemies, then hand in hand
We will walk to paradise -- again more blessed
I will to yon promonts top, and there survey,
What shipwrecked passengers the belgique sea
Casts from her foamy entrails by mischance.
Roar sea and winds, and with celestial fires,
Quicken high projects, with your highest desires.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Yet this is somewhat like, but brambles, you are too busy, were I at Luningberge, and you catched me thus, I should go near to ask you at whose suit, but now I am out of sent, And fear no sergeants, for I think these woods and waters are commonwealths that need no such subjects nay they keep not a Constable at sea, but a man is overwhelmed without order. -- Well, dry land I love thee, though thou swarm with millions of devourers, yet hast thou no such swallow as the sea.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Thou liest, there lives upon the earth more beasts
With wide devouring throats, than can be found
Of ravenous fishes in the Ocean:
The huge Leviathan is but a shrimp
Compared with our Balena on the land

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I am of your mind; but the Whale has a wide mouth
To swallow fleeting waters, and poor fish,
But we have Epicures and Cormorants,
Whom neither sea, nor land can hardly serve
They feed them fat, while arms and honour starve,
Desart looks pale as death, like those bare bones.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha -- amazed.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Seest thou them trembling, slave here were Arms?
That served the truthless state of Luningberge.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So do I sir serve the dukes son of the state,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I laugh to see how dastard fear
Hastens the death-doomed wretch to his distress,
Say didst thou serve the duke of Luningberge.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His son Otho sir, I am a poor follower of his
And my master is airing of himself at your Cell,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Is he that scaped the wrack young Luningberg?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Aye sir, the same sir, you are in the right sir.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Revenge I kiss thee, vengeance you are at liberty,
Wouldst thou having lost a father as I have,
Whose very name dissolves my eyes to tears
Could duty and thy love so different prove,
Not to avenge his death whose better part
Was thine, thou his, when he fell part of thee
Fell with him each drop, being part thine own
And wouldst not be revenged;

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes on the murtherer,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: On him, or any man that is assied
Has but one ounce of blood, of which he is part
He was my father, my heart still bleeds
Nor can my wounds be stopped, till an incision,
I have made to bury my dead father in:
Therefore without protraction, sighing, or excuses
Swear to be true, to aid assist me, not to stir
Or contradict me in any enterprise
I shall now undertake, or hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I swear.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Were I persuaded that thou couldst shed tears,
As doth the Egyptian serpents near the Nile;
If thou wouldst kiss and kill, embrace and stab,
Then thou shouldst live, for my invective brain
Hath cast a glorious project of revenge
Even as thou kneelest, wilt thou turn villain speak.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O sir when was I otherwise, from my creation nothing else, I was made of no other stuff, villainy is my only patrimony: though I be an irreligious slave, yet I bear a religious name, though I want courage, yet in talk, I will put them all down, though I have nothing in me that is good: Yet I will --

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Forbear thy Lord is coming I will go in
And royally provide for such a Prince,
Say thou hast met the kindest host alive,
One that adores him, with no less zeal
Than rich men gold, or true religious heaven
Dissemble cunningly, and thou shalt prove
the minion of my thoughts, friend to my love.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well sir never fear me this is an excellent fellow
A true villain fitter for me than better company,
sp.p: This is Hannce Hoffmans son. that stole down his fathers Anatomy from the gallows at Leningberge, aye it is the same upon the dead scull there is the iron Crown that burnt his brains out, what will come of this, I neither know nor care: but here comes my lord.
sp.l: How chers my most noble, my most honourable, my most gracious; yea my most grieved prince.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: A fearful storm

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And full of horror.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: Trust me Lorrique besides the inly grief
That swallows my content when I perceive
How greedily the fierce unpitying sea, and waves,
Devoured our friends another trouble grieves my vexed eyes
With ghastly apparitions, strange aspects
Which either I do certainly behold
Or else my soul divining some sad fate
Fills my imaginary powers with shapes
Hideous and horrid.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My lord let your heart have no commerce with that
Mart of idle imaginations, rouse up your nobleness
To apprehend comfort, kindness ease and what otherwise
Entertainment so solitary a place as this, can give the
Ancient subject of the state of Leningberg collect
It is I take it the son to that Vice-admiral that
Turned a terrible pirate.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: Let us turn back into the sea again
Yielding our bodies to the ruthless sound
That hath divided us and our late friends
Rather than see choice Hoffman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Courage brave Otho, he will use thee kindly.
Here he comes, sweet host here is the dukes heir of
Leningberge do homage and after entertain him and me his
Follower with the most conspicuous pleasures
That lies in thy poor ability.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Before I speak to my most sacred Lord
I join my soft lips to the solid earth
And with an honoured benison I bless
The hour, the place, the time of your arrive,
For now my savage life, lead amongst beasts
Shall be turned civil by your gracious help

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: I see thy true hearts love drop down in tears
And this embrace shows I am free from fears
My disturbed blood runs smoothly through my veins
And I am bold to call thee friend, bold to entreat
Food for by wrack I have lost ship, friends and meat.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: You that attend my Lord enter the cave
Bring forth the homely Cakes these hands prepared
While I entreat his excellence sit down
Villain bring nothing but a burning Crown.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: What is that thou biddest him bring, a burning Crown

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Still you suspect my harmless innocence
What though your father with the powerful state
And your just uncle duke of Prusia
After my father had in thirty fights
Filled all their treasures with foemens spoils
And paid poor soldiers from his treasury
What though for this his merits he was named
A prescript outlaw for a little debt
Compelled to fly into the Belgique sound
And live a pirate?

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: Prithee speak no more
Thou raisest new doubts in my troubled heart
By repetition of thy fathers wrongs

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Then he was wronged you grant but not by you,
You virtuous gentleman
Sate like a just Judge of the under-shades,
And with an unchanged Rhadamantine look,
Beheld the fresh mangled with many scars
Pared from the bones of my offended father
And when he was a bare anatomy,
You saw him chained unto the common gallows.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: Hoffman.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Nay hear me patiently kind Lord
My innocent youth as guilty of his sin,
Was in a dungeon hidden from the sun,
And there I was condemned to endless night
Except I past my vow never to steal
My fathers fleshless bones from that base tree
I know not who it was, I guess your mother,
She kneeled and wept for me, (but you did not)
Beseeching from that vow I might be freed
Then did I swear if Nations foreign power
Compelled me to take down those naked bones
I never would release them from those chains
Never entomb them, but immediately
Remove them from that gallows to a tree
I kept mine oath: look Luningberg; it is done
Behold a father hanged up by his son

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: O horrible aspect murtherer stand off
I know thou meanest me wrong

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: My Lord behold these precious twines of light
Burnt out by day eclipsed when as the sun
For shame obscured himself this deed was done
Where none but screech owls sung, thou receptacle
thou -- -- organ of the soul;
Rest, go rest, and you most lovely Couplets
Legs and arms reside, forever here
This is my last farewell, what do you weep?

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: O Lorrique I am betrayed, slave touch me not

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Not touch thee? yes, and thus trip down thy pride.
You placed my father in a Chair of state:
This earth shall be your throne, villain come forth
And as thou meanest to save thy forfeit life,
Fix on thy Masters head my burning Crown,
While in these Cords, I in eternal bands
Bind fast his base and coward trembling hands.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: Lorrique, art thou turned villain to my life.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will turn anything sir rather than nothing, I was taken life promised to betray you, and I love life so well, that I would not lose it for a Kingdom, for a Kings Crown, an Empire.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: On with the Crown.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: O torture above measure.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: My father felt this pain when thou hadst pleasure.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: Thy father died for piracy.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O peace, had he been judge himself, he would have showed
He had been clearer than the Crystal morn!
But wretches sentenced never find defence,
However guiltless be their innocence,
No more did he, no more shalt thou, no ruth
Pitied his winter age, none helps thy youth.

sp.speaker: Otho
sp.l: O Lorrique torture, I feele an Aetna burn
Within my brains, and all my body else
Is like a hill of Ice, all these Belgique seas
That now, surround us cannot quench this flame
Death like a tyrant seizeth me unawares,
My sinews shrink like leaves parched with the sun
My blood dissolves, nerves and tendons fail
Each part is disjointed, and my breath expires
Mount soul to heaven, my body burns in fire.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He is gone.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Go let him come Lorrique
This but the prologue to the ensuing play,
The first step to revenge, this scene is done
Father I offer thee thy murtherers son.

div1.stage: Florish. Enter Ferdinand, Rodorick, Lodowick, Mathias, Lucibet, Ierom, Stilt, attendants.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Princes of Saxony and Austria,
Though your own words are of sufficient weight
To justify the honourable love borne by Lodowick to bright Lucybell,
Yet since your parents live and as I hear
There is between them some dissension,
Blame us not for detaining you thus long
Till we had notice how the business stood

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: Your royal entertain great Ferdinand,
Exceeding expectation in our stay,
Bind us to thanks, and if my brother please
To hold his challenge for a Tournament
In praise of Lucibellas excellence,
No doubt our father and the Austrian duke
Will be in person at so royal sport.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We trust they will.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: I do assure your grace
The Austrian and the duke of Saxony
By true report of pilgrims at my cell
From either of their courts set hitherward
Some six days since.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thanks Rodorick for this news
They are more welcome than the sad discourse
Of Leningberg our nephews timeless rack
Which addeth sorrow to the mourning griefs
Abound in us for our Duchess death.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p:
Aye truly Princes, my father has had but hard luck since your coming to his court, for aught I know you are bred of ill weather, come before you are sent for, yet if my most gracious father say you are welcome, I his more gracious son take you by the hands, though I can tell you my mothers death comes somewhat near my heart, but I am a prince, and princes have
power more than common people to subdue their passions.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We know your worthiness is experienced in all true wisdom.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: True, I am no fool, I have been at Wittenberg, where wit grows.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Peace thou unshapen honour, my states shame,
My ages corsive, and my black sins curse,
O hadst thou never been, I had been then,
A happy childless man, now among men,
I am the most unhappy, one that knows
No end of mine, and of my peoples woes.
I tell you Princesse, and most gracious maids;
I do not wear these sable ornaments
For Isabell'as death, though she were dear,
Nor are my eyelids overflown with tears,
For Otho of Luningberg, wracked in the Soun,
Though he were all my hope: but here is my care,
A witless fool must needs be Prussias heir.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Well, if you were not my father, -- 'snails, and I would not draw rather than put up the fool, would I might never win this lady at tilt and tournament: as Knights, I defy you both, for her; even you Lodowick, that loves her, and your brother that loves you: look to me, Stilt, and I have practised these two days: 'snails god forgive me to swear, she shall not be carried away so.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We are glad to hear your grace so resolute.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: As I am a Prince, and a Dukes heir, though I say it myself, I am as full of resolution as the proudest of you all

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I thank Prince Lodowick he has bound my youth
To be the conquerors prize, and if my stars
Allot me to be yours, I will be proud,
For howsoever you seem not fashioned
Like me, and cunning Courtiers; I protest,
By some small love I bear thee in mine eye,
Your worthy beauty, wealth and dignity.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Heart you would not unhorse Hercules for her father, I will practice again at Dantzike, you say in the Dukes mead; I will meet thee Mathias: there is my glove. For a gauntlet, though my father count me a fool, you shall find me none.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Would I might never find thee anything,
For thou indeed art nothing in esteem,
My sad soul sinks with sorrow at thy sight.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Health to the right gracious, generous, virtuous, and valorous Ferdinand Duke of Prussia.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Hermet dost thou not know this young man's face?
Is it not Lorique, that met us at thy cell
With letters from our brother Luningberg?

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: It is that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I am no less.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: thou saidst thou wast my nephews playfellow,
Appointed to await his virtuous person,
How is it then thou wert so ill advised
To take the land away, and forsake thy Lord?
Whom I have never seen, nor never may,
Though in his life my hope and comfort lay.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Be it known right gracious: Lorrique had never so little grace, as to leave his loved lord for weather or water, for torture or fire, for death or for life, since I first came to move in a pilgrims proportion; much disguised, being so proper a man: but only for those six words; that I was sent wholly to give notice of his coming.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: But thou hast left him now sunk in the sea.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I left the ship sunk, and his highness saved, for when all hope had left Master and pilot, sailor and swabber, I caused my Lord to leap into the cock, and for fear she should be sunk with too much company; I capered out, and cut the cable: rouse, quoth the ship against the rocks, roomer cry I in the cock, my Lord wept for the company: I laughed to comfort him; last by the power of heaven,
goodness of stars, kindness of winds, mercy of the waves, our cock and we were cast ashore under Reeshopscurre, we clambered up, but having scaped drowning, were in danger of killing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What there betided you?

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.l: Marry my Lord a young villain, son of a damned pirate, a maid ravisher.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Be brief, what was he?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Clois Hoffman.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: O my heart! did the false rebel hurt his sovereigns son?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No my Lord, the prince so hought and hoft him, that he had no other help but to his heels, and then I, my good Lord, being roefooted, outstripped him in running, tripped him by strength, and in fine, finely cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Where is the villains body?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Marry even heaved over the scar, and sent a-swimming toward Burtholme, his old habitation; if it be not intercepted by some Seal, Shark, Sturgeon, or suchlike.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Where is our nephew?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: He intends to stay at the same hermitage, where I saluted your excellence, with news of my lords excellencies intent, to visit you; for that his apparel is somewhat seasick, and he wants shift.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A chariot, and rich robes attend Lorrique.
And his reward, be thirteen hundred dollars,
For he hath driven dolour from our heart.
Princes, and Princesse, in your kindest love,
Attend our person to the hermitage,
where we shall meet the heir of two great States,
Rich Luningberg, and warlike Prussias,
Otho living, we will disinherit our fond son:
And bless all Dantzike, by our son elect,
Hermet you have at home, a guest of ours,
Your little cell, is a great princes court;
Had you been there to entertain young Otho,
He would have took your welcome thankfully,
Where now he mourns, for want of company.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: I will go on before my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Ferd,
sp.l: Nay I am jealous of my approaching joy,
And fearful, any eye but mine, should gain
The pleasure of my glad divining soul;
Forward come all, in my delight take part,
He that is now glad, adds joy to gladness heart.
If there live ere a surgeon that dare say
He could do better: I will play Mercury,
And like fond Marsias flea the Quacksalver.
There were a sort of filthy Mountebanks,
Expert in nothing but in idle words,
Made a days work, with their incision knives
On my oppressed poor father: silly man,
Thrusting their dastard fingers in his flesh,
That durst not while he lived, behold his face;
I have fitted my anatomy
In a fair chain to; father this youth scorned
When he was set in an ascending throne,
To have you stand by him; would he could see,
How the case alters, you shall hang by him,
And hang afore him too, for all his pride,
Come image of bare death, join side, to side,
With my long injured fathers naked bones;
He was the prologue to a Tragedy,
That if my destinies deny me not,
Shall pass those of Thyestes, Tereus,
Iocasta, or Duke Iasons jealous wife;
So shut our stage up, there is one act done
Ended in Othos death; it was somewhat single;
I will fill the other fuller, if Lorrique,
That I have late sworn to be murders slave,
swears he will protest me to be Othos,
Whom Prussia his uncle unknown loves;
If I be taken for him well: O then!
Sweet vengeance make me happiest of all men:
Prussia, I come as comets against change:
As apparitions before mortal ends;
If thou accept me for thy nephew, so;
Uncle, I will uncle thee of thy proud life.
Father farewell, I will to the hermitage,
Where if I be received for Luningberg,
I will have thy dry bones, sanguined all over
With thy foes blood, Rhamnusia help thy priest,
My wrong thou knowest, my willingness thou seest.

div1.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Come Stilt, bestir your stumps; you know I must be a tilter.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: I my lord, I know you should be one, but I hope you are not so mad.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: what dost thou count it madness to run a tilt.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: I my Lord, for you that cannot sit a hobby, you will hardly manage your tilthorse.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Why? they say Stilt, that stone Mares are gentler, see if thou canst get me one of them.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: Not afore next grass; I could help you now to a stone mule, a stone ass.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Well, I will try one course with thee at the half pike, and then go, come draw thy pike.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: That is not your fit word; you must say, advance your pike, and you must be here sir, and here, you will never learn for all my teaching.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p:
I have answered you Stilt, that Princes have no need to be taught, and I have even determined with myself, not to run at tilt, least I hazard my horse and harness:
therefore I will to the court, and only see my new cousin, that they said was drowned: and then retire to my Castle at Helsen, and there write a new poem, that I have taken pains in, almost these ten years: It is in praise of picktooths.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: That will be excellent my Lord, the barbers will buy those poems abominably.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Nay sirrah, I will get a patent from the Duke, my father, for the Cum Priuilegio for that poem, Ad imprimendum solum; besides thou shalt have a privilege, that no man shall sell toothpicks without thy seal: my father says I am a fool, but I think I bestow my time to look out for setting a new nap upon his threadbare Commonwealth: Who is that knocks? who dares disturb our honourable meditation? hark Stilt, dost thou see no noise?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: No, but I hear a noise.

sp.speaker: Ierom.
sp.p: A hall then; my father and my new cousin: stand aside, that I may set my countenance, my beard brush and mirror, Stilt, that set my countenance right to the mirror of Knight-hood, for your mirror of magistrates is somewhat too sober. how likest me?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: O excellent! here is your casting bottle.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Sprinkle, good Stilt, sprinkle, for my late practise hath brought me into strange favour: ha mother of me, thou hadst almost blinded the eyes of excellence; but omnia bene, let them approach now, if I appear not like a Prince, let my father cashier me, as some say he will.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Cashier you? no, do but manage your body, and have here, and here your conges, and then quid sequitur, Stilt knows, and all the court shall see.

div1.stage: Enter Ferdinand leading Clois Hoffman: Mathias, and Lodowick leading Lucibella: Lorrique, with other lords attending: comming neere the chayre of state, Ferdinand Ascends, places Hoffman at his feete, sets a Coronet on his head, A Herald proclaimes.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ferdinand by the divine grace, prince of Heidelberg lord of Pomer, and Duke of Prussia, for sundry reasons him moving, the quiet state of his people especially: which as a witless and insufficient prince, disinherits Ierom Heidelberg his known son and adopteth Otho of Luningberg his sisters son, as heir, immediately to succeed after his death in all his provinces. God save Duke Ferdinand, and Otho his heir.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Amen, Heaven witness, how my heart is pleased,
With the conceit of Prussias after-peace,
By this election.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Why? but hear you father.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Away, disturb us not, let us in and feast,
For all our country in our choice is blessed.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Why, but Stilt, what is now to be done Stilt?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Nay that is more than I know: this matter will trouble us more than all your poem of picktooths, 'snails: you were better be unknighted than unprinced, I have lost all my hope of preferment, if this hold.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: No more Stilt, I have it here; it is in my head, and out it shall not come, till red revenge in robes of sire, and madding mischief run and rave: they say I am a fool Stilt, but follow me; I will seek out my notes of Machiauel, they say he is an odd politician.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: I'faith he is so odd, that he hath driven even honesty from all men's hearts.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Well, sword come forth, and courage enter in,
Breast break with grief; yet hold to be revenged:
Follow me Stilt; widows unborn shall weep,
And beardless boys with armour on their backs
Shall bear us out, Stilt we will tread on stilts,
Through the purple pavement of the court,
Which shall be, let me see, what shall it be?
No court, but even a cave of misery.
There is an excellent speech Stilt, follow me, pursue me, will acquire,
And either die, or compass my desire.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: O brave master, not a Lord: O, Stilt will stalk, and make the earth a stage,
But he will have thee lord in spite of rage.

div1.stage: Enter Rodorigo, and Austria's Duke, some followers.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sir since you are content, you here shall find,
A sparing supper, but a bounteous mind:
Bad lodging, but a heart as free, and generous,
As that which is fed with generous blood,

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Your hermitage is furnished for a prince.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Last night this roof covered the sacred heads
Of five most noble, fair, and gracious Princes,
Duke Ferdinand himself, and Otho his nephew,
The sons of Saxon, and the Austrian Princesse.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: O god! that girl, which fled my Court and love,
Making love colour for her heedless flight,

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Pardon great prince: are you the Austrian duke?

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Hermet I am, Saxons proud wanton sons
Were entertained like Priam's Firebrand
At Sparta: all our State gladly appeared
Like cheerful Lacedemons, to receive
Those Dæmons that with magic of their tongues,
Bewitched my Lucibells my Helen's ears.
Knocking and calling within.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Who traueleth so late? who knocks so hard?
Turn to the east end of the Chapel, pray;
We are ready to attend you.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Which is the way to Dantzike?

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: There is no way to Dantzike you can find
Without a guide thus late, come near I pray,

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: look to our horses, by your leave master Hermet,
We are soon bidden, and will prove bold guests:
God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: That should be Saxons tongue.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Indeed I am the Duke of Saxony.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Then art thou father to lascivious sons,
That have made Austria childless.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: O subtle duke, thy craft appears in framing thy excuse,
Thou dost accuse my young sons innocence:
I sent them to get knowledge, learn the tongues,
Not to be metamorphosed with the view
Of flattering beauty, peradventure painted.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: No; I defy thee Iohn of Saxony;
My Lucibell for beauty needs no art,
Nor do I think the vertues of her mind
Ever inclined to this ignoble course
But by the charms and forcings of thy sons.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: O would thou durst maintain thy words proud Duke.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: I hope great Princes, neither of you dare
Commit a deed so sacrilegious: This holy cell
Is dedicated to the son of peace;
The foot of war never profaned this floor,
Nor doth wrath here with his consuming voice
Affright these buildings; charity with prayer,
Humility with abstinence combined,
Are here the guardians of a grieved mind.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Father we obey thy holy voice;
Duke Iohn of Saxony, receive my faith;
Till our ears hear the true course thy sons
Have taken with my fond and misled child.
I proclaim truce, Why dost thou sullen stand?
If thou mean peace, give me thy Princely hand.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Thus do I plight thee troth, and promise peace,

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Nay, but thy eyes agree not with thy heart;
In vows of combination, there is a grace
That shows the intention in the outward face.
Look cheerfully, or I expect no league.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: First give me leave to view a while the person,
Of this Hermet, Austria note him well,
Is he not like your brother Rodorick?

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: He is like him, but I heard he lost his life
Long since in Persia, by the Sophies wars.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I heard so much my Lords, but that report
Was purely feigned, spread by my erring tongue,
As double as my heart, when I was young.
I am that Rodorick that aspired your throne;
That vile false brother who with rebel breath,
Drawn sword, and treacherous heart threatened your death.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: My brother! nay, then i'faith old Iohn lay by
Thy sorrowing thoughts, turn to thy wonted vein,
And be mad Iohn of Saxony again.
Mad Rodorick, art alive? my mothers son
Her joy and her last birth; o she conjured me
To use thee thus, and yet I banished thee:
Body of me; I was unkind I know,
But thou deservest it then; but let it go:
Say thou wilt leave this life thus truly idle,
And live a Statesman, thou shalt share in reign,
Commanding all but me thy sovereign.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I thank your Highness; I will think on it:
But for my sins this sufferance is more fit.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Tut, title, tattle, tell not me of sin.
Now Austria once again thy Princely hand:
I will look thee in the face, and smile, and swear,
If any of my sons have wronged thy child,
I will help thee in revenging it myself;
But if as I believe they mean, but honour,
As it appeareth by these justs proclaimed.
Then thou shalt be content to name him thine,
And thy fair daughter I will account as mine.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Ah Austria! it was a world when you and I
Ran these Careers; but now we are stiff and dry.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: I am glad you are so pleasant my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: It was my old mood, but I was soon turned sad:
With over-grieving for this long lost lad;
And now the Boy is grown, as old as I,
His very face as full of gravity.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Please your Graces enter,
I know the servants that attend on me
By the appointment of Duke Ferdinand
By this have covered.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Why then let us in: brother I trust, and brother
Hold you this land, Rodorick hold thou the other,
By heaven my heart with happiness is crowned,
In that my long lost brother now is found:

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: so run on fate, my destinies are good,
Revenge hath made me great by shedding blood:
I am supposed the heir of Luningberg,
By which I am of Prussia Prince elect.
Good: who is wronged by this? only a fool:
And it is not fit that idiots should bear rule.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My Lord I have as you enjoined, enticed Saxons elder son to talk with you: and here he comes with his most excellent, amorous, and admirable Lady.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Hast thou the Hermets weeds for my disguise?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: All ready, fit, fit in the next chamber, your beard is point-vice, not a hair amiss.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Faithful Lorrique in thy unfaithfulness:
I kiss thy cheek, and give thee in that kiss
The moiety of all my earthly bliss.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Good: I am half a Monarch: half a fiend Blood I begun in and in blood must end yet this Clois is an honest villain, he has conscience in his killing of men: he kills none but his fathers enemies, and their issue, it is admirable, it is excellent, it is well it is meritorious, where? in heaven? no, hell.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now friend, where is prince Otho?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sad, sir, and grieved.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Why? prithee why?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Alas I know not why.
The hermet Rodorigo talked with him
Somewhat of you, and somewhat of the Duke,
About surprising you and murdering Lodowick:
Or such a thing, nay sure it was such a thing.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Surprising me and murdering Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: By whom? by what complot?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sure by the Duke, the Duke is an odd old lad:
I know, this night there is set a double guard,
And there is some trick in that: but patience:
Here comes the Hermet: holy reverent man!

div1.stage: Enter Clois Hoffman like a hermet.

sp.l: Somewhat important, wings his aged feet
With speedy nimbleness: heaven grant that all be well.

sp.speaker: Clois.
sp.l: Princes in pity of your youth, your love,
Your vertues, and what not, that may move ruth,
I offer you the tender of your lives,
Which yet you may preserve: but if you stay,
Death and destruction waiteth your delay.

sp.speaker: Lod,
sp.l: Who hath conspired our deaths? speak reverent man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Duke of Prussia, doting on this face;
Worthy indeed of wonder, being so fair,
This night hath plotted, first to murder you;
The guard are set that you may not escape,
Within, without, and round about the court;
Only one way, through Prince Otho his lodging
Is left; here is the key, and for more proof
Of my great zeal and care, on with these robes.
Within are Grecian habits for your heads;
Nay if you love life do not stand amazed,
But take the path toward my hermitage,
Yet I advise you, that you go not in;
There may be plots too, for aught I know;
But turn down by the river, there is a way
Leads to a little Chapel; in that porch
Stay, till I visit you with better news;

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I will but call my brother, and then go.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That were a going never to return:
I will send him after you, be well assured.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: O god! the Duke of Prussia grown thus false,
such shows of friendship, and so little faith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come Lucibella let us embrace this mean,
Duke Ferdinand shall with a sorrowing heart,
Repent this base dishonourable plot:
Father, our fortunes if they sort aright,
shall with continual thankfulness requite
This virtuous and this charitable care:
Farewell: we will wait thee in the Chapel porch
Bring Prince Mathias our kind brother thither,
And thou shalt add good works to charity:
Once more farewell Lorrique; there is for thee,
Commend me to thy Lord, tell him this wrong
Of his false uncle, shall meet full revenge:
But do to him our duties. Come chaste, fair,
We must not now by tilt and tournament
Maintain thy honour: for thy champion Knight,
Is forced by treason to unwilling flight.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: so run to mischief: O my dear Lorrique!
When I have summed up my account of death,
And robbed those fathers of their lives and joy,
That robbed me of my joy, my fathers life,
Thus thy hand clasped in mine, we will walk and meditate,
And boast in the revenges I have wrought;
That done; I will seat thee by my throne of state,
And make thee rival in those governments,
That by thy secrecy thou liftest me to;
Shalt be a Duke at least.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I thank your Grace, but pray resolve me,
What you now intend,
To these three Princes Lodowick, and Mathias,
And the thrice beauteous Princesse Lucibell.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Death certain: call in Mathias, if my plot prove good, I will make one brother shed the others blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I am nimble as your thought, devise, I will execute what you command.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A precious villain: a good villain too:
Well if he be no worse; that is do worse,
And honey me in my death-stinging thoughts,
I will prefer him: he shall be preferred
To hanging peradventure; why not? it is well

div1.stage:
Enter Lorrique.
His sufferance here may save his soul from hell.
He comes; what news my faithful servant? where is the Prince.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He is talking with the lady Lucibell,
And when I said your Highness sent for him,
He began with courtly salutations,
To take his leave and to attend your grace.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Well god-a-mercy friend, thou gottest me grace:
But more of that at leisure: take this gown;
My cloak, a chair; I must turn melancholy.
Second whatever I say, approve my words,
That we may move Mathias to mad rage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: God save your excellence: what sad, dull, heavy?
Or are you now in meditation
Which part to take tomorrow at the Tilt?
The mead is ringed with tents of stranger Knights,
Whose rich devices, and caparisons
Exceed the Persian Monarchs, when he met
Destruction and pale death sent from the sword
Of Philips son, and his stout Macedons
Cheerily Prince Otho there is such a warlike sight
That would stir up a leaden heart to fight.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: For honour and fair Luicbell.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O Prince Mathias! it is ill combined
When honour is with fickle beauty joined.
Where is your most Princely brother?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot tell I left him with his loved Lucibell.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But she has got another love,
Dishonoured all this rich assembly,
Left the memorial of such infamy,
As cannot die while men have memory.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How? pray you how? what hath the princesse done?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: she with a Grecian is but new fled hence,
Belike some other love of hers before:
Our tilt and tournament is spoiled and crossed,
The fair we should defend, her faith hath lost.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fled with a Grecian? saw you them go Prince Otho?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Aye, aye, I saw them go.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And would not stay them?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My true servant knows,
How at the sight of such inconstancy
My gentle heart was smit with inward grief
And I sunk down with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'sdeath; what path? which way? that I may track her harlot-steps,
Fled now: gone now: I will go seek Lodowicke

sp.speaker: Clo-
sp.l: Nay then you add an irreligious work,
To their lascivious act; follow yourself,
I and my man will bear your company
Lorrique, as I think, thou namedest a chapel,
A Hermet, some such thing: I have lost the form.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I heard her say, she could not travel far,
He told her, they would rest the dead of night;
Near to a chapel, by a hermitage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Where is that chapel? where is that hermitage?
If you love honour Princely Luningberg,
Let us to that chapel: if you know the way,
That I may kill our shame, ere it see day.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I will guide you to the chapel, aid your arm,
In your revenge, against that Grecian,
But for the Lady spare her, she is fair.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I will do what I can; o hell of life!
Who, but a fool would strive to win a wife?
shall we call Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: no, it would smite his soul in sunder, split his heart,
If he should hear of such adulterate wrong,
Cover the fault or punish as you please:
Yet I would save her fain, for she deserves
pity for beauty.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nothing, no for nothing.
She is as harlots, fair, like gilded tombs
Goodly without; within all rottenness:
she is like a painted fire upon a hill,
set to allure the frost-nipped passengers,
And starve them after hope: she is indeed
As all such strumpets are, Angel in show,
Devil in heart: Come, come if you love me go.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Follow Lorrique; we are in the right way.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: To hell I fear: tush let all fear go by,
Who will shun a bad way with good company.

div1.head: Actus tertus.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are you not faint divinest Lucibell?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: No, the clear moon strews silver in our path,
And with her moist eyes weeps a gentle dew
Upon the the spotted pavement of the earth,
Which softens every flower whereon I tread
Besides; all travel in your company
Seems but a walk made in some goodly bower,
Where loves fair mother strips her paramour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This is the Chapel, and behold a bank,
Covered with sleeping flowers, that miss the Sun:
Shall We repose us till Mathias come?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: The Hermet will soon bring him, let us sit down
Nature, or art hath taught these boughs to spread,
In manner of an arbour over the bank.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, they bow down as veils to shadow you:
And the fresh flowers beguiled by the light
Of your celestial eyes, open their leaves,
And when they entertain the lord of day
You bring them comfort like the Sun in May.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Come come, you men will flatter beyond mean:
Will you sit down? and talk of the late wrong
Intended by the Duke of Prussia?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Fairest forget it, leave till we are clear freed hence,
I will defy him, and cause all the knights
Assembled for our purposed tournament,
To turn their keen swords against his caitiff head.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Prithee no more, I feele thy blood turn hot,
And wrath inflames thy spirit, let it cease;
Forgive this fault, convert this war to peace.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O breath sweet touch with what a heavenly charm
Do your soft fingers my war-thoughts disarm,
Prussia had reason to attempt my life
Enchanted by the magic of these looks,
That cast a luster on the blushing stars.
Pardon chaste Queen of beauty, make me proud
To rest my toiled head on your tender knee,
My chin with sleep is to my bosom bowed;
Fair if you please a little rest with me.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: No, I will be Sentinel; I will watch for fear
Of venomous worms, or wolves, or wolfish thieves:
My hand shall fan your eyes, like the filmed wing
Of drowsy morpheus; and my voice shall sing
In a low compass for a Lucibell.
Sleep sweet, perhaps I will sleep for company.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I thank you; I am drowsy, sing I pray;
Or sleep: do what you please, I am heavy, I;
God night to all our care: o! I am blessed
By this soft pillow where my head doth rest.
By my troth I am sleepy too: I cannot sing,
My heart is troubled with some heavy thing.
Rest on these violets, whilst I prepare,
In thy soft slumber to receive a share:
Blush not chaste Moon to see a virgin lie
So near a Prince, it is no immodesty:
For when the thoughts are pure, no time, no place,
Hath power to work fair chastities disgrace;
Lodowick I clasp thee thus, so arm clip arm,
So sorrow fold them that wish true love harm.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Art sure thou hast found them?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Look, are these they?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Adulterer: strumpet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O!

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: O!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Unhumane deed to kill both.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Both have abused our glory, both shall bleed,

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: how now! what have ye done? my Lodowick bleeds
Some savage beast hath fixed his ruthless fang
In my soft body: Lodowick I faint,
Dear wake; my Lodowick: alas what means
Your breast to be thus wet? Is it blood or sweat?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who troubles me?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who is that? Mathias.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I, accursed I,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Where is the good Hermet? thank him for his love
Yet tell him; Ferdinand of Prussia
Hath a long arm; some murderer of his
hath killed us sleeping.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Killed thee? o no! I trust the careful destinies deny
So hard a fate: it is I alone am killed.
Come Lodowick, and close up my night-veiled eyes
That never may again behold the day.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: What means Mathias?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hold me not Prince Otho.
I will revenge myself upon myself:
For Parricide for damned parricide:
I have killed my brother sleeping in the arms
Of the divinest form that ever held breath.
I have killed loves Queen defaced with my foul hand,
The goodliest frame that ever nature built
And driven the graces from the mansion
Wherein they have continued from their birth;
She now being dead, she will dwell no more on earth.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What moved you to it brother?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Jealous rage, suspicion by Prince Otho,
That Lucibell had fled with a base Greeke,
O me accursed! I am born to shame.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But I am wretcheder, that from the love
Devoted to the house of Saxony,
Have thus begot this monster cruelty:
I lay within an arbour, whence I saw
The princesse, and yourself in this disguise
Departing secretly my uncles court:
I judged you for a Greeke as you appeared.
Told Prince Mathias of your secret flight;
And he led on by fury followed you
Where thus deceased by night and your attire,
Hath robbed your heart of life, his own of joy.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Forgive me brother, pardon fairest maid,
And ere the icy hand of ashy death
Fold your fair bodies in this sable vail;
Discover why you put on this disguise.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To scape the lustful Duke of Prussia,
Who purposed this night to murder me,
And ravish her whom death hath made his pray
My Lucibell, whose lights are masked with clouds
That never will be cleared.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: My uncle, fie, who buzzed into your head
This damned lie?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: it is no lie.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: No lie: it is true, it is true,
The reverent Hermet Rodorick told it us.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: The Hermet is a villain damned in hell
Before the worlds creation, if he say it
My Princely uncle purposed such a thought.
Look to the Princesse, there is life in her:
Cheer up your heart Prince Lodowicke, courage man.
Your being of comfort may recover her,
While I bring forth the Hermet and disprove
This false assertion: Rodorick is a slave
A vile and irreligious hypocrite,
No Hermet, but a devil if he dare
Affirm such falsehood of Duke Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Rodorick is not as you report him sir,
Nor did he ere belie Duke Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: No did? why then did you maliciously
Advise Prince Lodowick and fair Lucibell
To fly the Prussian court this dismal night.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Who I? I spake not with them,

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: Yes ye did.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Where was it that he spake with you? tell us where?

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: At Dantzike in the Duke of Prussias court.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Who heard him besides you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The Princesse Lucibell.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: As heaven shall help my fleeting soul, I did.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: why speaks my dukedoms hope in hollow sounds?
Look up fair child here is Saxony and I
Thy father, Lucibella look on me;
I am not angry that thou fleddest away
But come to grace thy nuptials; prithee speak.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Father I thank you: Lodowick reach me thy hand
How cold thou art; death now assails our hearts,
Having triumphed over the outward parts;
Farewell a while, we die but part, to meet
Where joys are certain, pleasures endless, sweet.
Father, this latest boon of you I crave,
Let him, and me, lie in one bed, and grave.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: O me! o miserable wretched me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hover a little longer blessed soul, glide not away too fast: mine now forsakes his earthly mansion and on hopes gilt wings will gladly mount with thine, where Angels sing celestial ditties to the King of Kings. brother adieu, your rashness I forgive, pardon me father, pardon; Austria your daughter is become a bride for death: the dismal even before her wedding day. Hermet God pardon thee: thy double tongue hath caused this error: but in peace farewell. He that lifts us to Heaven keep thee from Hell.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O strange conjecture! what should move this Prince
To charge me with such horrid cruelty?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I will tell thee hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Stay Mathias stay,
It is thy uncle Rodorigo, and besides,
My honour and Duke Austria's shall be gaged,
He never parted from our company in his own hermitage
Since day declined, and glimmering twilight ushered in the night.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Not from his hermitage?

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: No not he.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: By Heaven he did not.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Then there is villainy, practice, and villainy
Mathias hath been wronged and drawn to kill
His natural brother, with him to destroy
The rarest piece of natures workmanship,
No doubt by practise and base villainy
The Hermet not at court? strange! wondrous!

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: O for my son, and Austria's worthy child.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Thou weepest in scorn, and very tear of thine
Covers a smile: Saxony, I defy
All truce, all league of love, guard thee proud Duke;
Thy sons have made me childless; I will have thee
Consort in death with my wronged girl and me.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Help Prince Mathias: Hermet, o the Heavens!
The Austrian Duke sinks down upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Proud Iohn of Saxony: hast thou no wound?

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Not any Austria; neither touched I thee.

sp.speaker: Aust.
sp.l: Somebody touched me home: vain world farewell
Dying I fall on my dead Lucibell.

sp.speaker: Saxo.
sp.l: Sir what are you that take on you to part?
It is by your weapon that the Duke is fallen.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: If I thought so, I would fall upon the point,
But I am innocent of such an ill:
Kill my good kinsman, Duke of Austria;
Then were Prince Otho of Luningberg set down
In sad despairs black book to rave and die,
But I am free from such impiety.

sp.speaker: Saxo.
sp.l: Are you Prince Otho of Luningberg?

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: He is, and heir apparent to Duke Ferdinand

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Maybe the Moon deceives me, and my grief
As well in the distinguishing of sounds,
As sight: I have heard of young Luningberg,
And seen him too at Hoffmans overthrow,
He looked not like you, neither spake like you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Father, it is he: Lorrique his man attends him,
That fellow which is all composed of mirth
Of mirth? of death: why should I think of mirth
After so foul a murder? come lend hands
To give this Princely body funeral rites,
That I may sacrifice this hand and heart
For my peace-offerings on their sepulchres.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Nay, boy, thou shall not leave old Saxony
Childless for all this sorrow: Prince, and if Otho
Help in my son with noble Austria,
Lodowick shall be my burden: brother yours
The lovely but the luckless Lucibell.
So tread a heavy measure; now let us go
To inter the dead, our hearts being dead with woe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There is life in Lucibell, for I feel
A breath, more odoriferous than balm
Thirle through the coral portals of her lips,
Apparent signs of life, her pulses beat;
O if I could but yet recover her,
It would satisfy the State of Austria,
That else would be disturbed for want of heirs
Heaven be propitious, guide my artless hand,
To preserve fainting life in this clear form.
Grant this thou soul of all Divinity,
And I will strive whatever mortal may
To serve thee on my knees both night and day,
Tarry Prince Otho and see their bodies balmed,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I pray you think me not in passion dull;
I must withdraw, and weep, my heart is full.
O reverent man, thou bearst the richest fruit;
That ever fell in the unripened spring,
Go lay her soft, she had ill fate to fall;
But rich or fair or strong, death swallows all,
Hola! Lorrique, leave our horse; draw near.
Help me to sing a hymn unto the fates
Composed of laughing interjections.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why my good Lord? what accidents
Have chanced, that tickle so your spleen?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: O my dear self: thou trusty treasurer of my revenge,
Kneel down, and at my bidding kiss the earth;
And on her cold ear whisper this strict charge:
That she provide the best of her perfumes,
The fat of Lambs rapped from the bleating Ewes,
The sweet oft smelling wood she can devise;
For I must offer up a sacrifice,
To blessed occasion that hath seconded
With opportune means my desire of wreak;

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now I have kiss it the earth, let me partake
In your great joy, that seems to exceed.
Are Lodowick, and the Princesse murdered?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: It is done, go, hie thee to Prince Ferdinand;
Tell him how misadventure and mistrust
Hath killed Prince Lodowick and bright Lucibell:
By Prince Mathias hand: add to that chance,
Another unexpected accident:
Say that the Dukes of Austria and Saxony,
Being by the Hermet Rodorick entertained,
And hearing outcries in the dead of night,
Came and beheld the tragic spectacle,
Which sight did so enrage the Austrian Duke,
That he, assailed the Saxon, but fell slain,
On his pale daughter, now deflowered by death.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Is Austria then slain by Saxony?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Come, come, he is dead, either by him or me,
No matter, he is gone: there is more to go.
Run with the news; away.

div1.stage: Enter Stilt, and a rabble of poore souldiers: old Stilt his father, with his scarfe like a Captaine. A scuruy marcb.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: Father, set you the army in qeraye, while I invocate:
The General Foulkes: Fibs, foreman, and
Friends all, Officers ail, help to marshall; Prince
Ierom my Lord shall remunerate, that, is shall be
Full of thanksgiving, while nature is able to
sp.p: Nourish, or sustain; Father you have order to stay the rest, be sententious, and full of circumstance I advise you; and remember this, that more than mortality fights on our side; For we have treason and iniquity to maintain our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Old Stilt.
sp.l: Hah! what sayst my son? treason and iniquity?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Reason, and equity I meant Father; there is little controversy in the words: but like a Captain courageous, I pray go forward, remember the place you are, in no more, but this; the days of old, no more, but that; and the glory Father; Knighthood at least, to the utter defacing of you and your posterity, No more but foe.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.p:
Well, go thy ways: thou art able to put fire into a Flint stone; thou hast as rheumatic a tongue to
persuade as any is between Pole and Pomer; but thou art even kit after kind, I am thy father, and was infamous for my exprobations, to discourage a dissembly of tall soldiers afore thou wert born, and I have made them stand to it tooth and nail; how say you, most valiant and reprobate Country men: have ye not heard I have been a stinger, a tickler, a wormer.

sp.speaker: Fibs.
sp.p: Yes; noble, ancient Captain Stilt, ye have removed men's hearts I have heard that of my father (God rest his soul,) when ye were but one of the common all soldiers that served old Sarloys in Norway.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.p: I then was, and Sarloys was; a gentleman would not have given his head for the washing; but he is cut off, as all valiant cavalieros shall; and they be no more negligent of themselves; But to the purpose: we are dissembled together, and fallen into battle beray in the behalf Prince Ierom a virtuous Prince, a wise Prince, and a most respectless Prince; my son Timothies master, and the unlawful heir of this land. Now sir the old Duke has put out a declamation, and says our rising is no other than a resurrection, for the Prince inspires not against his father; but the Duke inspires against his son, using him most naturally, charitably, and abominably, to put him from intercession of the crown; wherefore as ye be true men, and obstinate subjects to the State uncover your heads, and cast up your caps and cry a Ierom, a Ierom,

sp.speaker: Om,
sp.l: A Ierom, a Ierom, a Ierom.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p:
Most noble Countrymen I cannot but condole in joy, and smile in tears to see you assembled in my right, but this is the lamentation that I poor Prince must make, who for my fathers proclamation am like for to
lose my head; except you stand to me, for they are coming on with bows, bills, and guns, against us: but if you be valiant, and stand to me lustily, all the earth shall roar but we will have victory.

div1.stage: Enter with Drum, and Colours, Duke Ferdinand, Hoffman Lorrique, Captaine to leade the drum the souldiers march and make a stand; Allon Ieroms side cast vp their caps and cry a Ierom.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Upon those traitors valiant gentlemen:
Let not that beast the multitude confront,
With garlic-breath and then confused cries
The Majesty of me their awful Duke,
Strike their Typhoean body down to fire
That dare against us, their sovereign conspire.

sp.speaker: Ier,
sp.l: Come, come, you shall have your hands full, if you
Come where we have to do, stand to it Stilt.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: stand to it? here is the father and the son will stand, though all the rest fly away.

sp.speaker: O Stilt.
sp.p: I warrant you Prince, when the battle comes to joining, my son and I will be invisible, if they overcome us, I will give you leave to say I have no pith in me; upon them true Prince upon them.

div1.stage: An Alarum: Hoffman kneeles betweene the Armies.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: I thought it would come to that;
I thought we should bring
The false Prince on his knees.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: What means my Dukedoms hope to turn thus base? arise, and smite thy foes.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: I see them not my most honoured uncle; pity I beseech
These silly people, that offend as babes,
Not understanding, how they do offend:
And suffer me chief agent in this wrong,
To plead their pardons with a peaceful tongue.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: We scorn pardons, Peace and pity; we will have a Prince of our own choosing, Prince Ierom.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Prince Ierom or nobody; be not obstacle old Duke, let not your own flesh and blood be inherited of your Dukedom, and a stranger displaced in his retority: for and you do, we will take no comparison of you and your army, but fall upon you like temperance and lightning.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Upon your peril; gentlemen assail.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: If any bosom meet the brunt of war,
Mine shall be first opposed; these honest men
That rise in arms for my young Cozens right
Shall be Protected whilst Prince Charles can stand.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Why see now what a thing Majesty is;
Stilt and the rest of my good people; my cousin
Charles looking but in the face of our excellence
Cannot choose but take our part.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: Nay but trust him not my Lord; take heed of him,
Aware your enemies at any hand.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Why should you make this intercession
For these base abjects, whose presumptuous hearts
Have drawn their rebel bodies against their head:
Entreat not for them, they are all but dead.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Forbear a little worthy Countrymen.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Nay we deny that, we are none of your Countrymen; you are an arrant arrant Alien.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.p: True son a mere peregrination, and one that was not born within our Dukes damnation, and therefore not to be remitted to any upstantial degree of office amongst us: that is the fine, that is the confusion of all.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: But hear me.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Aye, aye, pray hear him; nay I charge you all upon pain of death that you hear my cozen.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: he Well we will are him: come on, speak, what will ye say?

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: O I beseech you save your lives and goods,
For the Dukes squadrons armed with wrath and death,
Watch but the signal when to seize on you,
That can no more withstand their approved strengths
Than sparrows can contend with towering hawks:
Or against the Eagles eyrie:
This act of yours by gathering to a head,
Is treason capital, and without grace
Your lives are forfeit to extremest law.

sp.speaker: O Stilt.
sp.l: Mass he says true son; but what is the remedy?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: None at all father, now we are in, we must go through stitch.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Yes, there is remedy: cast your weapons down,
And arm yourselves with mercy of your Prince
Who like a gracious shepherd ready stands
To take his lost sheep home in gentle hands.
As for your Prince, I will for him entreat
That he may be restored again in love,
And unto offices of dignity, as either Taster,
Sewer, Cupbearer, the place himself thinks
Fittest for his state, and for my part when
That unhappy time of Princely Ferdinands
Sad death shall, come: --
Which moment: --
But should I as I say behold that hour,
Although I am elected for your Prince,
Yet would I not remove this gentleman,
But rather serve him as his councillor.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Give me your hand of that Cozen; well said, now get a pardon for me, and my merry men all; and then let me be my father's Taster, being the office belonging to his eldest son; I Being the same, and then you shall see me behave myself, not as a rebel, or reprobate, but as a most reasonable Prince, and sufficient subject.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p:
Well since my Lord has said the word, bring that of spake he to pass and ye shall have my word too, and old Stilt my fathers, being a man of good reproach I tell you,
and condemnation in his country.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.p: Aye that I am my Lord, I have lived in name and shame these threescore and seven winters, all my neighbours can bear me testament, and accord.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Well, rest ye quiet, Sovereign on my knees
I beg your Highness grant to their request:
Suppose them silly, simple, and your own;
To shed their blood were just, yet rigorous,
The praise of Kings is to prove gracious.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: True soul of honour substance of myself,
Thy merit wins thee mercy, go in peace,
Lay by your unjust arms, live by your sweat,
And in content the bread of quiet eat.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: God save Duke Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Pray Father, forgive me, and my man,
And my man's father by our single selves;
For we have been the capital offenders.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.l: Aye truly my Lord, we raised the resurrection,

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: I pardon all; give thee my Tasters place:
Honour this Prince that hath thus won you grace.

sp.speaker: O: S., Y-S.
sp.l: God save Duke Ferdinand, and Prince Otho.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Aye and me too.

sp.speaker: O. Stilt.
sp.p: And Prince Ierom too; well son, I will leave thee a Courtier still, and get me home to my own desolation, where I will labour to compel away excessity: and so fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: This business over: worthy nephew Charles,
Let us go visit the sad Saxon Duke,
The mourning Hermet,
That through affection wrought his brothers fall.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: I will wait your Highness to that house of woe,
Where sad mischance sits in a purple chair,
And underneath her beetle cloudy brows
Smiles at unlooked-for mischiefs; o there
Doth grief unpainted, in true shape appear.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Shrill trumpets sound a flourish
For the cries of war are drowned.

sp.speaker: Ier,
sp.l: Nay but cozen cozen, is it not necessary I wait
Upon mine own father? and Stilt upon me?

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: It is most expedient, be obsequious.
No doubt his excellence will like that well.

div1.stage: Enter Lorrique like a French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Dieu vou guard Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Welcome my friend, hast any suit to me?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Away Monsieur, if you be the grand Prince
Legitimate of Prussia, I have for tender
To your Excellence de service of one poor
Gentle home of Champaigne.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: I am not he you look for gentlemen,
My cozen is the true and lawful Prince.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Aye sir I am the legitimate, and am able to entertain
A gentleman though I say it and he be of any quality.

sp.speaker: Sarl,
sp.l: Lorrique, now or never play thy part:
This Act is even our Tragedies best heart.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Let me alone for plots, and villainy,
Only commend me to this fool the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: I tell thee, I am the Prince, my cozen knows it,
That is my cozen, this is Stilt my man.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A vostree seruice Mounsieur most Genereux.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: No doubt he is some cunning gentleman
Your Grace may do a deed befitting you
To entertain this stranger.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: It shall be done cozen; I will talk with him a little
And follow you, go commend me to my father
sp.p: Tell him I am coming, and Stilt, and this stranger, be mindful cozen, as you will answer to my Princely indignation.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Well sir, I will be careful, never doubt;
Now scarlet Mistress from thick sable clouds
Thrust forth thy blood-stained hands, applaud my plot,
That giddy wonderers may amazed stand
While death smites down suspectless Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: Sweet Prince I scarce understand this fellow well, but I like his conceit in not trusting Prince Otho; you must give him the remove that is flat.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I be, gar, he be chose against you, he give you good word so be that, but he will have one fisgig or dia by gar for company on in principality be no possible.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Well, I apprehend thee, I have a certain Princely feeling in myself that he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Hold ye there my Lord, I am but a poor fellow and have but a simple living left me; yet my brother were he a very natural brother of mine own, should he be adopted, I would adopt him, and inherit him, I will fit him.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Aye but how Stilt, but how?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By gar my Lord, I will tell you fine knacks, for make him kick up his heels, and cry we, or be gar I be hang, and so shall I be too, and for the grand love I bear you, for de Lady Issabella's sake your most tres-excellent Lady moder.

sp.speaker: Ier,
sp.l: Didst, thou know her French doctor? didst thou?

sp.speaker: Silt.
sp.l: Aye as beggars do the Ladies that are their Alms givers.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By gar you lie, like Iacknape, I love the Lady. With a boone coeur, and for her sake here take this same, and this same, put this in de cup, where the competitor Prince Otho shall drink; by gar it will poison him bravely.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: That were excellent my Lord, and it could be done, and nobody know on it.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Aye, but he always drinks in my Fathers cup.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Aye so let be, let the Duke drink of the same.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: What poison my father? no, I like not that so well.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You shall drink too, and I too, and when we be sick, as we shall have a petit rumble in de belly; dan take of this same, and give your father this: but your cousin none of it, and by gar nobody shall be dead, and kicka, and cry o, but Otho.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: That is excellent, master.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: This is the poison then, and this is the medicine?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Aye that be true.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Well Physician, attend in my chamber here, till Stilt and I return; and if I pepper him not, say I am not worthy to be called a Duke, but a draw-latch.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Farewell awe, and iebbit a vow; and we speed by thy practice we will crush a cup of thine own country wine.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Go speed to spoil yourselves:
Doctor lie there, Lorrique; like thyself appear
So now I will post unto the Hermitage, and smile
While silly fools act treason through my guile.

div1.head: Actus quartus.
div1.stage: Enter Ferdinand and Sarlois, open a curtaine: kneele Saxony, the Hermet and Mathias: tapers burning.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: See Princely uncle the black dormitory,
Where Austria and Prince Lodowick are laid
On the cold bed of earth, where they must sleep
Till earth and air, and sea consume by fire.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Their rest be peace, their rising glorious;
Sad mourners, give your partners leave to kneel,
And make their offertory on this tomb,
That does contain the honourablest earth
That ever went upright in Germany,

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Welcome Duke Ferdinand, come, come, kneel, kneel,
Thus should each friend another's sorrow feele.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Is Lucibella in this monument?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No, she is recovered from deaths violence;
But through her wounds and grief distract of sense.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Heaven help her, here she comes:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Kneel still, I pray.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O me accursed! why live I this black day!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O a sword, I pray you kill me not,
For I am going to the rivers side
To fetch white lilies, and blue daffodils
To stick in Lodowicks bosom, where it bled,
And in mine own; my true love is not dead,
No you are deceived in him, my father is:
Reason he should, he made me run away;
And Lodowick too, and you Mathias too;
Alack for woe, yet what is the remedy?
We must run all away: yet all must die.
It is so, I wrought it in a sampler,
It was heart in hand, and true loves knots and words,
All true stitch by my troth: the posy thus:
No flight dear love but death, shall sever us;
Nor that did not neither; he lies here does he not?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Yes lovely madam, pray be patient.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I so I am, but pray tell me true,
Could you be patient, or you, or you, or you,
To lose a father and a husband too:
Ye could, I cannot; open, door here ho!
Tell Lodowick, Lucibell would speak with him;
I have news from heaven for him, he must not die,
I have robbed Prometheus of his moving fire:
Open the door, I must come in, and will,
I will beat myself to air, but I will come in.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Alas her tender hands smiting the stone
Beweep their mistress rage in tears of blood.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Fair Lady be of comfort, it is in vain
To invocate the dead to life again.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Aye gentle Daughter be content, I pray,
Their fate is come, and ours is not, far off.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Here is a hand over my fate hath power
And I now sink under the stroke of death,
But that a purer spirit fills my breast
And guides me from the footsteps of despair,

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: A heavenly motion full of charity,
Yourself to kill you self were such a sin
As most divines hold deadly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Aye but a knave may kill one by a trick,
Or lay a plot, or foe, or cog, or prate,
Make strife, make a man's father hang him,
Or his brother, how think you goodly Prince,
God give you joy of your adoption;
May nor tricks be used?

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Alas poor Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Aye that is true, I am poor, and yet have things.
And gold rings, and amidst the leaves green
Lord how dee, well I thank god, why that is well,
And you my Lord, and you too; never a one weep,
Must I shed all the tears? well he is gone,
And he dwells here ye said, ho I will dwell with him,
Death, dastard, Devil, robber of my life
Thou base adulterer, that partest man and wife
Come I defy thy darts.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: O sweet forbear.
For pities sake a while her rage restrain
Lest she do violence upon herself.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O never fear me, there is somewhat cries
Within me no: tells me there is knaves abroad
Bids me be quiet, lay me down and sleep
Good night good gentlefolks, brother your hand,
And yours good father, you are my father now,
Do but stand here, I will run a little course
At base, or barley-break, or some such toy,
To catch the fellow, and come back again,
Nay look thee now, let go, or by my troth
I will tell my Lodowick how ye use his love:
So now good-bye, now god-night indeed:
Lie further Lodowick take not all the room,
Be not a churl, thy Lucibell doth come.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Follow her brother, follow son Mathias,
Be careful guardians of the troubled maid;
While I confer with Princely Ferdinand
About an embassy to Austria,
With true reports of their disastrous haps.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, I will be her guardian and her guide,
By me her senses have been weakened,
But I will contend with charitable pain,
To serve her, till they be restored again.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: A virtuous, noble resolution.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Worthy Prince Rodorigo, when tempestuous woe
Abates her violent storm, I shall have time
To chide you for unkindness, that have lived
In solitary life with us so long.
Believe me Saxon Prince you did us wrong:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Would I might never live in no worse state;
For contemplation is the path to heaven.
My new conversing in the world is proved
Luckless and full of sorrow; fare-ye-well
My heavens, alone, all company seems hell.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: My nephew call for wine my soul is dry
I am sad at sight of so much misery.

div1.stage: Enter Ierom and Stilt, with cup, towell, and wine.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Is the Dukes taster there?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: I am at hand with my office.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Fill for the Duke good cozen, taste it first.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: I have no mind to it Stilt, for all my antidote.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: I warrant you Master let Prince Otho drink next,

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Here cozen, will you begin to my father?

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: I thank you kindly, I will not be so bold,
It is your office; fill unto my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Well god be with it, it is gone down, and now I will send the medicine after; Father pray drink to my cozen for he is so mannerly that he will not drink before you.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Pray ye do my Lord, for Prince Otho is best worthy of all this company to drink of that cup, which if he do, I hope he shall never drink more.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Good fortune after all this sorrow Saxony.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: O worthy Ferdinand, fortune and I are parted, she has played the minion with me, turned all her favours into frowns, and in scorn robbed me of all my hopes, and in one hour overturned me from the top of her proud wheel.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Build not on fortune, she is a fickle dame
And those that trust unto her sphere are fools.
Fill for his Excellence.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Here cozen for your Excellence, pray drink you to the Duke of Saxony.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Not I kind cozen, I list not to drink.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Gods Lady, I think Stilt, we are all undone, for I feele a jumbling worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: O give the Duke some of the medicine

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: What medicine talkest thou of? what ails my son?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: O lord, father, if ye mean to be a lives man take some of this.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Why? this is deadly poison unprepared.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: True, but it was prepared for you and me by an excellent fellow, a french Doctor?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: Aye, he is one that had great care of you.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Villain what was he? drink not Saxony
I doubt I am by treason poisoned.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Heaven keep that fortune from my dread Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Treason ye Princes, treason to the lives
Of Ferdinand the Duke of Prussia
My Princely master! Otho of Luningberg

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Who should intend us treason?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This fond Prince.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Never to you Father, but to my cozen Charles; indeed I meant to poison him, but I have peppered myself.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: I never gave thee cause.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: That is nothing to the purpose, but my Lord took occasion by the council of a French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Physicians for the Duke, my uncle faints.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: Surgeons for the Prince, my master falls.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Call no Physicians, for I feel it too late,
The subtle poison mingled with my blood
Numbs all the passages, and nimble death
Fleets on his purple currents to my heart.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Father, I am dying too, o now I depart, Be good to Stilt my man, he was accessory to all this.

sp.speaker: Stils.
sp.p: Aye truly: was I sir therefore I hope you will be good to me, I helpt to mingle the poison as the French Doctor, and my master charged me.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: What is that French Doctor?

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: What is become of him?

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: We left him in the court in my masters chamber.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Aye sir woe worth him, farewell Stilt, farewell fathers
I ask you pardon with repentant eyes;
Fall stars, O Stilt, for thus thy master dies.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Take hence that traitor for the fool his man.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.l: I pray provide for me sir;

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Let him be tortured, then upon a wheel broke like a traitor and a murderer.

sp.speaker: Stilt,
sp.l: O lord sir. I meant you no hurt, but to Prince Charles

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Away, disturb us not with idle talk.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Provide quoth he if you call this providing, pray let me, provide for myself, alas my poor father, he will creep upon crutches into his grave when, he hears his Properest Stilt is cut off by the stumps.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Hence with that fellow.

sp.speaker: Stilt.
sp.p: Pray, not so hasty, you would scarce be so forward, if you were going as I am, to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: How cheers my royal uncle

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: Like a ship that having long contended with
The waves, is at last with one proud billow
Smit into the ruthless swallow of the sea.
For thee alas I perceive this plot was laid;
But heaven had greater mercy on thy youth,
And on my people, that shall find true rest
Being with a Prince so wise and virtuous blessed.
Farewell most noble Iohn of Saxony,
Bear thy unmatched grief with a mind bent
Against the force of all temptations;
By my example Princely brother, see,
How vain our lives and all our glories be.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: God for thy mercy! treason upon treason,
How now young Otho what art thou poisoned too?

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Would God I were, but my sad stars reserve
This simple building for extremer ruin:
O that French doctor.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Aye that worst of hell.
No torment shall content us in his death.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Nay soft and fair, let him be taken first;
How now sad brother, are you come to see
This Tragic end of worthy Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I heard of it too soon, and come too late.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Well brother leave the Duke, and wait on me;
Mathias, and the heartgrieved Lucibell
Shall go with us to Wittenberg, and shun
That fatal land filled with destruction.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: But Lucibella like a chased hind
Flies through the thickets, and neglects the briars,
After her runs your Princely son Mathias,
As much disturbed, though not so much distract,
Vowing to follow her, and if he can,
Defend her from despairing actions.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: And we will follow them, Prince Otho adieu
Care goes with us, yet we leave grief with you,
Inter your uncle, punish traitors crimes,
Look to your person, these are dangerous times,

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Lords take this body, bear it to the court,
And all the way sound a sad heavy march,
Which you may truly keep, then people tread
A mournful march indeed,
Go on afore, I will stay awhile, and weep
My tributary tears paid on the ground
Where my true joy your Prince my uncle fell:
I will follow to drive from you all distress
And comfort you, though I be comfortless.
Art not thou plumped with laughter my Lorrique,
